They were very busy but didn't seem harried...the hostess was accommodating as well. My hubby doesn't like to sit in close proximity with other diners and on a busy night you will rub elbows with I'm sure some great people... so she found 2 great spots at the bar for us to eat and drink. 
Our bartender, Rob, introduced us in a very friendly manner, to his Carolina Reaper Pepper infused vodka and tequila. He shared how he come up with idea while fiddling around with the peppers one night bartending.We will return to this fine place for another very HOT Bloody Mary, which had a great garden of yummy things in it.. I had an amazing Belgian quad beer. It seems like a great place for the locals around Monroe street but we felt right at home being patrons from Monona. My son recommended this place and we're so glad he did. Our burger and pulled pork flatbread were so tasty. The aioli for each was great. 
I had :THE JACS CLASSIC* $12
Grilled Knoche's ground beef, cheddar,
lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions,
classic aioli, hamburger bun with great fries (frites) 
My hubby had : Flatbread- PULLED PORK $17
BBQ sauce, pulled pork, red onion,
cheddar, arugula and red cabbage slaw
We both loved our drinks and meals and will surely return... maybe for brunch on Saturday or Sunday for the chicken special.

Went there for "brunch" brunch with my sister on aSataurday morning. A smalll .and quaint place with limited seating but you don't feel crowded. Small bar where one could peek inside the kitchen.  Breakfast items include benedicts or just eggs  and bacon toast and breakfast fries consisting of sweet potatoes as well as regular potatoes. MY poached egg was overlooked  and I gave the note to the cooks. But overall it was a tastey meal.  There are also sandwiches.   Service was attentive and friendly. good prices for quality food.

Good beer list.  Pretty solid food.  Not my go to place but I definitely find myself wondering why I haven't gone to Jacs in a while. 
Hubby and I ordered the short rib appetizer - definitely would order again. (highlight)  
I ordered a chicken sandwich and he ordered the steak sandwich special. But nothing to write home about. Steak was a bit over cooked for medium and chicken sandwich is a chicken sandwich. ?
The spicy tequila drink is not that spicy. 
Good for a random Tuesday night pretty quick dinner though!

What a heaven for the gluten-free (and the normal hungry folks)! Food is solid and the kitchen is really flexible and able to make most things sans gluten. Frites (can be made gluten free) are great and come with 4 dipping sauces that (I think) rotate occasionally. The soups and burgers are solid. The walnut burger in particular is solidly delicious. 

The atmosphere is fine but nothing special. There is one main dining area, which is a little small and open with a door to the outside right in the middle. Depending on where you sit there are occasional cold breezes from the open door or throngs of people standing over you as they wait for a table. Probably best for groups of 4 or fewer. 

Jac's is probably best for some of its special nights, including wine night on Mondays where you can get drinks and apps for not many monies...

We needed to find a restaurant with gluten free food for our daughter with Celiac. This place was knowledgable on cross contamination and almost everything could be made GF and they have a dedicated fryer. Terrific service & food!

Wow. I am floored. I arrive a little after 5 for my highly anticipated Gluten Free Fish Fry Friday. My honey is home sick but I really wanted a nice Friday night dins. I get there. It's busy, no seats at the bar, but there are 3 open tables. I ask the hostess for a table for one for dinner. She looks at my apologetically and says she's sorry but she cannot seat me. The dinner tables are meant for parties of 2 or more. I can wait 20 minutes for a bar table that can seat 1. Did I mention there is no seat at the bar to wait? I drove over from the East Side for this! Being gluten free this is my favorite place to eat in Madison. I would estimate my partner and I come here at least once every 3 weeks. We consistently leave 25% tips. This is how they treat single diners! I even had the hostess check with the manager to see if I could be seated in the dining area but it was denied. Un-f&*king-believable!

I would probably only rate this place a 4 maybe a 4.5 but I will round up because of the gluten free options.  Having a nice place to go that can satisfy people with Celiac's disease and those without is a big bonus.  Their frites are amazing and come with various tasty aiolis.  It is a small place so it can be awkwardly uncomfortable when super busy for both seated tables and those waiting as there isn't much room to prevent hovering.  I have been there for dinner and was impressed by their tap selection and large variety of dining options.  Went to brunch this weekend and lucked out for timing as we had no wait but watched it fill quickly with Iowa/WI fans.  Brunch cocktails are affordable - $4 mimosa!  Service can be interesting we saw a party of 4 come in, wait, get ignored and walk out looking at their phones for a new option.  They were also "out of the cinnamon roll" but given the time we were there after opening I think they just hadn't gotten around to prepping them....  I was hoping that I was going to love the crab cake eggs benedict, however, I was definitely underwhelmed by both flavor and texture.  The crab cake was pretty bland and very mushy.   Thankfully I ordered frites as my side so I was decently satisfied. My boyfriend got the classic breakfast and raved about the bacon.  Nice ambiance and in a great location on Monroe St.  Will be back with a friend for gluten free cheese curds!

This update is to let all of you that since I last wrote this review, every time i've been to Jac's has been stellar. Everything I said before still holds, but I've consistently had some very good meals there. Also, note that this place is very vegetarian (but not quite vegan) friendly. So friendly that they serve up two types of veggie burgers: Quinoa/Black Bean, and Lentil/Walnut (Last I checked anyway, the menu changes frequently, which makes it worth going back to more often). The Quinoa/Black Bean is a bit more tasty, but both are well worth trying. It's probably my favorite spot in town to get American style food for dinner.

Yep, this is the place. Close to home, and excellent, always great service. Last time I went in for my signature and theirs Mussels and frets. The mussels were tough, the waitress took them back and apologized and got me a new bowl of the most tasty, best mussels ever.  Thank you! When good service is hard to come by you all went above and beyond.  I've had some wait staff that were kinda sullen, but always polite and food, well its always top.

Shame on me for my previous one liner review. Deserves a much longer write up.

- No reservations, but can call ahead to get on the list.
- Gets cold if sitting by door or windows when cooler temps. (bring a coat)
- Friendly/helpful waitstaff & bartenders
- Crispy well seasoned frites
- Flatbreads are excellent to share
- Almost also items can be made gluten free
-  All Beer, Wine and Alcohol is 1/2 off during Happy Hours.
                         Monday-Thursday 4pm - 7pm
                         Friday & Saturday 4pm - 6 pm

Have yet to have a bad meal. Food always served piping hot. Staff is attentive. Making sure waters are filled and everything is ok. Bartenders are always making sure no hand is empty.

On one occasion we called about 30 mins ahead cause we were coming from Beaver Dam. So we got on the list and said there was a 30 minutes wait. Then we arrived and actually ended up waiting for additional 45 minutes rather than 10 minutes. Which was totally cause we planned on having drinks too. But then one of us finished their beer before being seated and the next beer and the cheese curds that we had also ordered while waiting they said was on the house for the long wait. Thought that was a nice gesture on their part.
Great little atmosphere, but dinner was not that great. I think when we go back it will be for drinks and apps and from looking at what others were ordering, that might be the way to go.

Really solid little bistro. Fast, friendly, attentive service from our server (she's from Prague and gets extra points for being Czech). Great drink selection. Everything you would expect. Two of us ordered steak frite which came well done for some bizarre reason. Default temp on menu stated the correct medium-rare. Server had correct temp orders to us in a few minutes - fantastic recovery. Will probably split my time between Jacs and Brasserie IV going forward. Both do similar things and have their own pluses and minuses.

Great beers and atmosphere. My smoked salmon blt had a very minimal portion of salmon but was still delicious. At $11 it was reasonably priced with a small side salad.

Also, I like this place bc it's not overly popular and I haven't had to wait for lunch or dinner.

I would visit jacs again. I think it would be a great place for happy hour.

Any other gluten free, cheese lovers out there? Have you been envying everyone enjoying their cheese curds? Well, don't be too sad! Jacs has GF cheese curds! To make it better? My party had cheese curds all around town, and said that the GF ones at Jaks were their favorite. Wisconsin needs to up there game now that Jacs has mastered the GF cheese curd. They even have a gluten free night on Wednesdays!

Our whole group left with full tummies of sandwiches and salads. After a lot of cheese curds, I decided to round out my dinner with a beet and goat cheese salad. The beets were earthy and juicy! Yum! Enjoy all that Jacs has to offer.

This is a fantastic restaurant with incredible food and superior service...  A quaint atmosphere which is surprising with the bar area located so close.  This is a special place for date night and we enjoy neighborhood.... We should have saved room for desert........  Check it out....and yes, make reservations.... It is always packed.

Jac's is the saving grace of Monroe Street. Delicious, reasonably-priced, traditional Americana food in a well-lit, clean, cozy space that can be described as bar-meets-restaurant. The drinks are fabulous, and the Bloody Mary could be a meal in itself with all of the add-ons. Attentive staff, great atmosphere. Will be back.

I wanted to update my review because I have recently had their fish fry and I have got to say...BEST IN MADISON. I have been looking for a good, traditional fish fry in madison and Jacs hits the nail on the head. The breading is crispy and the fish is nice n flaky on the inside.

Small place - definitely recommend reservations. I watched them turn away at least 4 groups before 5:30pm! (we got there at 4:50pm) Had a filet special and the mac & cheese. Both were wonderful! Interesting beer list, in a good way.
My favorite bloody in Madison.  Jeff is my favorite bar tender in Madison.  This combo makes it my favorite bar in Madison.

Good brunch and good beer selection!

If you like eggs benedict, Jac's brunch menu is basically a bunch of different versions of eggs benedict along with some sweet items like a home made cinnamon roll topped with strawberries and cream. I got the crabcake benedict; it didnt blow me away, but it was still good. The crabcake didnt seemed to have a good amount of crab by volume, so i did not feel ripped off at all.

What was awesome was the frites with the sauce trio. Man, you get a nice big cone of fries with 4 different aolis: house special, herb, spicy, and cranberry. My favorites are the house special and the herb aolis. The fries themselves are fairly crispy with a nice, chewy body. It was such a treat!

I didn't order any beers, but their tap selection was good. There were about 1 beers, and they were all at least solid craft choices. The ones that stuck out to me were Romantic Chemistry by Dogfish Head and a barrel-aged stout from Central Waters.

I'd love to come back for some frites after work with a friend some time!

I love their bruled grapefruit and cinnamon rolls for brunch. The burgers are delicious and I also love their salads (the brussle sprout salad is my favorite). My daughter always gets the noodles and cheese off the kids menu and it is SO good! I end up eating half of it. There are so many delicious options, not to mention their extensive drink options. My husband likes to try new local beers. This is one of our favorite places to come in Madison.

Great place for lunch, the sandwiches always leave me happy. Soups are made in house and for the most part ROCK, best clam chowder I've ever had.  

Great beer, AWESOME happy hour (as far as I can tell they have it everyday and it's HALF OFF EVERYTHING) and tasty specialty drinks.  I had a Wisco Sour ... or three (you have the option of having it served the old traditional way, with an egg white. TRY IT!  Sooooooo good!). Dinner is really great, we usually go on Mondays (half off bottles of wine).  

The entree section is fairly small, but still hard to choose from (and the sandwiches from lunch are still available... it can take me and hour to order, I swear).  From my experience I'd say you can't go wrong with the Chicken Fran... something-or-other (super tasty, rich cream sauce), the Risotto or the Mussels (with a big cone of fries that I NEVER can finish, the sauce is a different story).  LOVE the Peach Flatbreat; we do that with HH all the time, it's new and it better not leave!!  

They have brunch on the weekend, with $2 mimosas (so much better than the Come Back, I'm willing to pay $2 more, plus they are HUGE).  

We don't take our daughter much (because we usually intend to hit up the HH for a while first :)  but when we do they always give her toys to play with and the servers are really nice!  I never feel bad about her squeals because it gets pretty loud anyway :)  I'd say it's child friendly for lunch and an early dinner early in the week, but not so much on the weekends.  Can't really rate the children's menu, since she isn't really eating off of it yet... I think I remember seeing a hummus sandwich option that sounded great.  Over all I'd say it's one of our favorite spots to go!  

Service is always great, we get a "Cheers" vibe from the place (the bartenders remembered us from our first visit which I though was really sweet).  

a few tips: weekends are crazy, so is happy hour; get there early and stake claim on some seats at the bar and put your name in for a table if you want to eat in the dining room.  It can get loud... but it's gotten a lot better (they have a metal ceiling, so it's never going to be quiet, lol) happy hour adds to this I think, so if you really want some quiet go later.  GET A CAB!  Seriously, Belgian beer is potent and you really can't have just one (or if you are my husband, just 5 :) not to mention there always seems to be some kind of special going on that sucks me in... we've had to call it in a couple of times... now we just go prepared :)  

OH and even my family from up north found something they liked!

I went here for a work lunch, not expecting much in the way of vegan options, and it turned out that they had a delicious one! Our server was extremely helpful in asking the kitchen how to modify the lentil and quinoa burger to make it vegan. They offered a roasted red pepper ketchup instead of the aioli, which was delicious! I don't even normally like mushrooms, but they cooked the mushrooms so well, I just wanted to keep eating them! They had a vegan soup of the day when I was there, too, which I had, and it was great. The one thing I wish is that they would mark the vegan options, and add more! That would make me a lot more likely to go back, as I have vegan friends, and we're not interested in going out somewhere that we will all be ordering the same thing.

Jac's, the reincarnation of a couple tries at restaurants in this near-West side Monroe St. space in recent years, does a lot of things right.  These include:

- vibrant, fun and comfortably crowded full-service bar and dining room that lends a neighborhood and low-key vibe to the place 

- an expansive French bistro-style menu with well-executed soups and salads for starters, classics such as moules frites (in your choice of three wine-based baths), entrées such as duck breast - perfectly cooked medium-rare, and an array of delicious side items such as roasted brussels sprouts (if you think you hate them, think again)

- a great lunch menu with an array of sandwiches to tempt any tastebuds. Try the salmon on flatbread with aioli for a real treat.

- nice specials, such as half-off bottles of wine on Monday nights

- a commitment to rustic and local foods that really demonstrate a restaurant's understanding of the particular Madison style that has taken hold in the city's top dining venues


My criticisms are few:

- the prices are high: entrées come close to, match and even surpass some of the city's more ambitious eateries. This is an issue at Jac's, because the food is very good in almost all cases but...

- ...the ambiance is lacking.  The serviceable but uninspired décor is a letdown, particularly when such effort has gone into crafting a French bistro or gastropub-style menu

- the Friday night fish fry is a major disappointment; it's not particularly cheap and the fish lacks flavor.  The Laurel just next door does a much better job.

Jac's is a restaurant with a loyal following and a great deal of potential to attract an even larger fanbase.  To do so, a revamping of the dining room to match the ambitious menu, a honing of the overly expansive menu, and a check-in with what some other restaurants are doing, a bit more successfully (e.g. Sardine), would really bump Jac's up into the next echelon of Madison staples where it seems to want to be.  Alternately, Jac's could consider slightly lowering their prices to better match the décor and casual service, and things would feel a bit more correctly aligned.  

Bottom line: a promising spot with good bistro-style food, but needs some polish and attention to detail to become a true contender.

As I'm writing this, I'm sitting at my coffee table eating my leftovers from Jacs last night. (Um, Yum!) My boyfriend and I had a date night and for some reason I was hard-core craving a turkey sandwich... so, of course we went to the restaurant that serves the best turkey sandwich in Madison, Jacs! 

I've been to Jacs multiple times over the past five years and I've never been disappointed. It's a small restaurant located on Monroe Street, although, there's usually a never a wait and parking is always abundant. It has a cozy intimate vibe. In the winter make sure you sit away from the door because it can get a little chilly. In the summer make sure you walk down to Lake Wingra and watch the sunset after grabbing a bite to eat. 

Just a heads up-- the current menu online is different from the menu that they offer in the restaurant. My boyfriend was a little disappointed that menu item he had picked out online was no longer being offered in the restaurant. Nonetheless, he was able to find a chicken and prosciutto sandwich that he absolutely loved. My go to drink is a margarita, which is not listed on their drink menu,  but was still deliciously mixed up by the bar tender... Over the summer I was able to have a tasty cocktail with an edible flower floating in it (check out the posted picture!) 

Not the best for large parties but great for a date night or a dinner with friends. Definitely check out Jacs, and order my go-to turkey sandwich!

The food is ok though I waited 25 minutes for a salad during lunch and the restaurant was almost empty. The customer service is non existent.  Recently fell in the restaurant due to food on the floor.  The manager laughed.  The owner promised me her insurance company would contact me and that she would send me a gift certificate. SHE DID NOTHING.  Never called me back, never contacted me.  SHAME on them.  DON'T GO.

Pretty good burgers although can be inconsistent. Fries were too greasy. Acoustics in this place are bad though, and also sitting close to the door (which is easy to do since the place is crowded) you can stay chilled if it's cold outside and the door keeps opening. That's not a comfortable or fun atmosphere. You can keep your coat on but that's not comfortable either.

I can sum up my dinner experience as bland, with the exception of the frites, which were very good.
I ordered an appetizer of frites with aioli, which for $4 was a good deal because it was a huge serving. They were nicely seasoned with coarse salt and seasoning (black pepper? Not sure)

 I ordered the tofu sandwich with side salad.  Side salad included greens, grape tomatoes, and red onion.  This was fine, although the vinagrette dressing was very bland, tasting mostly of olive oil.  As for the tofu sandwich, it was not good.  It was a slab of breaded pan-fried tofu.  So...it was basically like eating a slab of plain tofu.  There was some pesto aioli but it was barely noticeable. As for my companions burger, it was fine, but nothing special (the burger patty was of a nice size at least).  During our time there, our water was never refilled--we didn't get quite to the bottom of our glasses, but close.  Overall, meh--I'm not returning to this place except maybe if I wanted a beer and some frites.  Go to Brasserie V on Monroe instead.

After spending hours browsing Yelp for somewhere new to try, I decided on Jacs because it's just down the street from my work (and somehow I'd never noticed it?) My favorite thing about Madison is its plethora of "New American" restaurants/gastropubs with simple menus and amazing french fries. Jacs is just that.

My boyfriend and I called when we were about 15 minutes away and asked to put our name on the list. When we walked in, it was packed--really no room to even stand and wait--but thankfully our name was called after about a minute! Unfortunately, our table was right next to the bar and there was a large party waiting to be seated. They weren't seated for 15 - 20 min so it was a bit unpleasantly crowded for us.

I ordered the Bourbon Burger and it was delicious. My only complaint is that the ciabatta roll was too big for the patty so I had to take several bites in to actually get to the meat. I ordered the frites, and they were weirdly short but the house aioli was INCREDIBLE. I need a recipe asap.

My boyfriend got the steak frites (note: if someone in your party is ordering this, you should probably opt to get a salad instead of frites of your own. HUGE portion.) I had never liked steak...until last night. I had a couple bites of his and it was incredibly tender and the sauce was amazing. Totally worth the price.

Our waiter wasn't super friendly, but he was efficient, which I appreciate (no long wait for drinks or the check!)

I will definitely be back. Cozy atmosphere, delicious aioli, great selection of beers on tap! Go early or call ahead, it's a small space and can get very crowded.

I WAS SO HAPPY TO BE ABLE TO EAT OUT.

I'm back for EPIC, and as a new Celiac, I was worried about not being able to eat out at all with my coworkers. Alas, I found Jacs through both Yelp and Find Me Gluten Free, and they delivered more than I could have expected. It was smaller than I thought based on pictures, but very cozy and the waitress was awesome. 

Food was good, first of all. The cheese curds were not heavy or very oily, and the dip it came with was really yummy. This was very easy to share with my coworker. I think this was automatically GF?

Serving sizes were big. Even though we got small salads, they were huge! Lots of cheese curds, lotta salad, big main dish, and even a big creme brulee! Ffffffff.

Lastly, I didn't have to explain at all about my Celiac/allergy, which made me very, very, very happy. This is my biggest gripe with eating out. It's been over 24 hours and I have not had a reaction, so I feel safe to say that this is Celiac friendly.

Whenever I come back for training in the future, I plan on coming here. Continue being awesome!

(Pictures coming later)

My friend and I met here for dinner.  We both ordered burgers and were sad to find out they don't have pretzel buns anymore.  The burgers were pretty good, but the highlight for me was the fries!  I'll be back for those fries alone!  I also had the bloody mary made with dragon's milk beer.  It was really good and filled with lots of toppings!

It helps that this place is two blocks from my apartment.
The bartenders make excellent cocktails, my personal favorites being the Brooklyn and the New Fashioned. They also serve a wide variety of belgian beers that go along very well with the frites.

Stop in for the happy hour 4-7pm for 1/2 off all of their drinks. I go once a week if I'm in town. It's a small place, so it tends to get packed.

Have only eaten there once  and had polenta which was  quite good. I love the atmosphere and the bar, but I also hope to stop in more for the food.
Nice atmosphere and the frites were great but we expected the meals to be more flavorful and we found the drinks to be overpriced. More welcoming to kids than many similar restautants.

Pretty decent walleye fish fry, excellent clam chowder, good burgers, good fries. My aunt swears by the smoked salmon blt. Only real complaint I have is that they seem to use a lot of gluten free buns for their daily specials, which, in fact, tastes like cardboard.

Excellent service. Solid food. Will definitely go back. Especially appreciate their attempt to lower the noise level by adding panels to the tin ceiling. Probably need to add some to the walls. No one in our party had eaten here before. Everyone enjoyed the experience. Beer choices were also great.

The food is delicious and consistent.  Great beer selection.  Fries are amazing.  Burger is small but tasty.  Catch of the day never disappoints.  Highly recommend this place for a casual dinner and brunch.  AND they have gluten free fish and chips...WHAT!?!?!  They fry gluten-free in a separate fryer.
Good beer selection. Very bland food. Small portions and over priced.

We stopped by for happy hour. The bloody marys were average at best. The bartender was an exquisite jerk. Rude, negligent, and brusque, he charged us full price for our drinks, and after we pointed out that it was happy hour, he stated "oh yeah, the only reason you're here." 

We didn't eat anything, so I'd feel bad totally slamming the place, but man, get your service mentality together guys. That was just bad.

We went out to Jacs to give it a try and I found a truly welcoming little spot along the specialized storefronts and restaurants of Monroe Street.  While the place bills itself as European-inspired, I found instead a comfy locavore place that was a little upscale, but not immensely overpriced and certainly enjoyable. 

The highlight? Their cheese plate: it featured four bits of local cow, goat or raw milk cheese and -- wait for it -- a "snit" of New Glarus beer. On the platter. 

This is what I love about Wisconsin.

Highlights/lowlights

1) outstanding gluten free selection
2) cute location
3) wide variety of menu items

I can't believe that as someone with celiac disease it has taken me this long to come to Jacs! 

The great location on Monroe St. With a free parking lot makes this a hassle free outing. The ambience is cute, pub like and the service is about average but not bad.

What really makes Jacs stand out is the unique menu options and massive gluten free menu! The cuisine is American. You can get sandwiches, pizza, pasta, burgers etc. Jacs has gluten free pizza crust AND buns AND pasta AND a separate fryer. I only saw one thing on the entire menu that Jacs said they couldn't modify to be gluten free. We tried the frites with the dipping sauces (including a sage and a cranberry sauce) as an appetizer. I had the gluten free Mac and cheese with bacon and ham (so bad for you I'm sure, but so good!). Both items I tried were great and everyone I was with enjoyed their meals. 

I will absolutely be returning to try some of the other entrees!

met some friends here for dinner last night. a reservation had been made, but it still somehow took us 30 minutes to be seated. (strike one.)

this place is tiny... if you're waiting for a table, there's really nowhere to go that isn't in the way of the hostess and waitstaff. hooray for standing by the door on a cold, rainy night! (strike two.) 

then there's the crowd. these waspy, snotty yuppies are why i rarely venture to monroe street. they make my skin crawl. it's like they all stepped out of the pages of a j crew catalog. barf.

we were FINALLY seated, and things were great after that. the server was pleasant and timely for the most part. the beer list is small-ish but solid. i ordered the mac and cheese and it was really, really good... probably the best i've had in a restaurant (although the bacon didn't hurt). i felt like the prices were a bit steep, but overall we were all very happy with what we ordered. i would give jacs four stars for the food, but the reservation snafu and the no waiting area thing didn't make for a great first impression.

I came here last week to grab a beer with friends. Love the selection of beers. I can see my husband and I coming back for some brews. If you consider yourself a "beer snob" then you'll love what they offer. If you're looking for Miller, Coors and those are your staples, you won't find them here. 

Also have nice nightly specials. The night that I stopped in was 2-1 burger night. I didn't order food, but other's plates looked very appetizing. Prices are a little high for what I'm comfortable with, but if the special works for you, it's a good value. Beer is priced well.

Atmosphere is nice and cozy, waitstaff is friendly and courteous. 

All in all, I will definitely be going to jacs again. Check it out!

I enjoyed it here! Made a reservation for 3 people which I definitely recommend - it's a very small place and was busy at 7:45pm on a Monday night (which also causes it to get a bit loud). We had great service. The beer selection is excellent but a little pricey. I had the Sage Chicken sandwich with frites. It was very good but nothing absolutely spectacular. Overall a good experience and I would go back!
Excellent mussels and fish fry. Our only complaint was that we weren't told there was an up charge for the walleye.

Kind of an awkward environment when busy because there is no space to wake, and people are forced to stand in front of the door hovering over adjacent tables. Beer is overpriced for Madison. Food is good but nothing special, just basic American bar fare made a bit fancier.

Not only is the food great here (especially for lunch) the service is amazing! My friend and I come here for lunch once a month and now the waitress knows us and is so sweet. Their clam chowder on Fridays is AMAZING! So is the Friday special the walleye sandwich. Highly recommend.

Their menu options give gluten free eaters a large variety of food. The french fries were amazing as well as the gluten free breads used. This is the perfect place for those looking for a restaurant that understands gluten free needs.

As you get nearer, the aroma of delicious grilled and charred beef meets your nose in a whirlwind of sensory overload that forces you through the doors of jacs. Do not fight this sensation.

This may have (definitely was) one of the best meals on a recent trip to Madison. The jacs classic burger was outstanding. The juicy grass-fed cow, sweet caramelized onions, and sourdough burger bun in particular were the stars of the show. It's a large burger, and my wife and I easily split it. We got the salad instead of frites, and it was a great accompaniment to the burger. We did try someone else's frites, and those were also delicious, though with the burger it'd be a heavy meal.

I would definitely return, and though I'd love to try the walnut burger, I don't know if I could tear myself away from getting another classic. Don't be a nincompoop, get it medium-rare for supreme juiciness. Why can't all burgers be that good?

This is my absolutely favorite place to eat/drink. I have to eat gluten-free for medical reasons, and Jacs has hands-down the best gluten-free fish fry, plus the only gluten-free cheese curds in Madison. They also offer a variety of gluten-free beers/ciders, but I usually get their barrel-aged Manhattan; it's the best!

Not sure what to make of Jacs. For starters, the place is VERY small so I would advice to make reservations if you're looking to dine on a weekend. That being said, you have no arm room between you and other diners. It's hard to hold a conversation with your group because the noise travels and makes the place extremely loud. 

I think my boyfriend and I came on a down day. We decided to have dinner there and called ahead to reserve a table. Not even 15 minutes after being there, a group of 10 comes in and basically takes over the bar. They were very loud, obnoxious and rude in some instances. Our table was less than 10 feet away from the bar so we were beyond annoyed at their behavior as well as other customers. Not fault of Jacs establishment . The Bartender had to ask them to please settle down. It really made the experience go downhill fast. 

As for the food, we started off with the frites with Aoli. Not bad. Fries were homemade as well as the sauce. However, they hardly gave us enough Aoli for the large amount of fries we received but still, it was a good starter. 

My boyfriend ordered a jacs burger with a side of clam chowder. The chowder was good. Tasted homemade. He seemed to enjoy it. I got the Mac n Cheese but subbed out the pork for chicken. It wasn't bad but it was soooooooooo  darn cheesy I couldn't eat it! I love cheese but the dish was just overwhelmed with it tall that it was impossible for me to eat more than 6-7 bites. 

The next day, I heated up the leftovers for lunch and could not believe how much oil was at the bottom of the the bowl. About a good 5 tablespoons was sitting under the noddles. I am assuming this was the fat that came from the cheese. 

Honestly, 2 people really could share the dish because it's a lot for one person to eat.


I'm reluctant to say anything bad about Jacs because I feel like I can give them another chance. They were far from bad but I expected better based on the reviews I read on Yelp. I will probably dine there again but I'm not dying to get back anytime soon.

Rating? TBD...

Frites, bacon wrapped almond stuffed dates and beer list were excellent. Cheese curds were 2nd only to the Old Fashioned.  Some work on cocktail execution and ironing out kinks with seating would push it over the top! Great addition to the Madison restaurant scene!

First review on Yelp so I'll try and make short and sweet. Frites are the best!! Start out with them as an app and enjoy the delicious sauces. Really good revolving tap list and can't go wrong with local brews.  Very small local so may be a wait if you do not have reservations. Good gluten free and veggie options as well.
The food was good, but it's small inside and it was crowded and very noisy. It was a Saturday night, so I would think a week night would be different.

A dim restaurant meets bar feel. The ambiance reminds me a lot of Brasserie V. I really like that the menu is interesting and different without being over the top. For example, the three little pigs sandwich has swiss, bacon, ham and pork belly on it - something simple but with a funky twist. The cheese curds weren't the best I've had but they were definitely good. The only thing I didn't like was my soup (a pumpkin/tomato something).

I didn't love everything I tried but really liked a lot of it and am excited to go back and try more from this interesting menu!

WTF? They used to make great fries here and now all they have is deep fried  diced potatoes Gross! Get it together Jac's there are too many good restaurants in Madison to phone it in on a Friday night.

There are multiple reasons for which I could highly recommend Jacs, but the most significant would easily be the gluten-free friendliness. The menu is largely gluten-free or available as gluten-free and the staff is very understanding as well. They even offer a gluten-free fish fry and New England Clam Chowder on Fridays. While not traditional, both are tasty. My wife and I can't wait to go back. If it helps, the drinks are great, too!

Frites are perfectly fried and well seasoned. Had the roasted beet salad and would highly recommend. The large portion was a generous amount and ingredients were fresh and incredibly flavorful. Add a ginger soda and you're set for a light lunch. Also, comes with four slices of baguette.

Been here twice now and both times were about equally satisfying! I like their expansive menu, the service, and the ambiance of the restaurant. However, the food is really just slightly above average.

A fantastic place for people with Celiac disease, they can make every single item on their menu gluten-free! This was a huge treat for one of my friends who has Celiac.

Back to the food...I tried their Friday fish fry and it was...alright. Large portions, but nothing to write home about. I tried their seared duck the second time I went, which was delicious, but a fairly small portion and relatively expensive ($21). Their cheese curds are also about just average.

This place does NOT take reservations, but you can call ~20 minutes ahead and they'll put your name down. Keep in mind that they require your full party to be there in order to get seated, though.

I want to like this place more, but between the long wait we usually end up having, and the barely above-average food, I don't see myself coming here too often. It's also fairly small so I wouldn't bring parties of larger than 6 here! If you're in the area and looking for an upscale-ish restaurant, I would check this place out, but there are definitely better alternatives.
Craving french fries but have gluten allergies? No fear at Jacs! A designated gluten-free fryer and gluten-free menu add up to a delicious meal. Be sure to try the assorted ailois with the fries!

First time for me at Jac's. Over the years, I've heard rave reviews from friends about this place. We arrived a little before 5 on a Thursday night and were asked if we had a reservation (for a table of 3). We didn't, and they were able to seat us right away. Only 2 other tables were sat at this point. Within 30 minutes, the restaurant was pretty packed as it doesn't seat too many. We were seated right next to the door, which is not that great when it's cold outside. Two of three of us were blasted with wintry freezing air every time the door opened (not great). One of my dining companions had to put a winter jacket back on to remain somewhat comfortable to dine (he was also getting bumped into my people coming in and out of the restaurant). My salmon sandwich was ok. The salmon was overcooked, but the selection of items on it were tasty (choice of white or wheat bread). The frites were tasty on the side (your choice of frites or salad on the side). They serve a special house sauce for the frites. My companion had to ask for ketchup for his burger. I'm not sure if we'll be back. We all stated that the food was ok, but not earth shattering delicious.

Great food, perfect atmosphere for a casual drink or lunch/dinner.  I'm really looking forward to going here again soon.

We tried the moules et frites, the garlic and chardonnay variety. Delicious and a meal in itself. My significant other had the pulled pork sandwich which is served on ciabatta that accompanied and held the pork and bbq. The bbq had great flavor without  taking over the pork.  

I went with the smoked salmon BLT and was delighted. I can't believe I never thought of that before.  When I go back again it will be hard to not order it again.  

The frites that are served with the moules are huge and very good. They also had two soups, one lemon chickpea, the other a southwestern chowder.  So, not your typical soup options either. I love places like this!

Very good place. In addition to top notch typical pub food, they have an excellent selection of gluten free options, both for food and drink. This sets jacs apart from other similar places. Worth a return visit.

Best fries anywhere!  Real Belgian style fries with aioli, excellent burgers with interesting tap beer selections.  A great neighborhood bar that doesn't try to do too much- it just has great food, beer, and service for a reasonable price.  Brunch is also excellent and ALMOST EVERYTHING can be served gluten free so I can dine with my Celiac friends.  Love this place.

Honestly one of my favorite places in Madison- I think this place is very underrated. The ambiance is nothing fancy but everything I've had to eat here has been absolutely delicious including some really good cocktails. The fries with the dipping sauces are to die for!! The duck and burgers are also good. The waitstaff has always also been amazing. It's really hard to come up with something negative about this place.

I liked Jacs from the moment I walked in - the decor was warm and unpretentious, yet still feels like a nice restaurant. It *almost* made me feel like I was in a restaurant in a city bigger than Madison. The bar deserved 4.5 stars. The Belgian beers, on tap or by the bottle, are wonderful - although I would prefer if they could keep their tap beers at varying temperatures, since my Belgian was a bit colder than it should have been. That's not really something to complain about, as it's perfectly lovely to sit at the bar and wait for it to warm up. The mixed drink list (using some word play, and not obnoxiously) and wines seemed well thought out and down to earth - I'm looking forward to ordering a martini on my next visit.

The food was good, but somewhere closer to 3 stars. We started with the pear and brie flatbread, and enjoyed it quite a bit. It has a cardamom honey drizzled on it that you notice, but doesn't overwhelm the dish. The frites are, indeed, wonderful. Eat them quickly, because they lose their flavor and texture upon cooling more than most french fries I've eaten (yes, I know - who wants to eat cold fries? but as I eat and talk, I don't want them to depreciate so quickly). My tofu sandwich had excellent texture, but was a bit blah. I had hoped they would have marinated the tofu. My husband had the portabello sandwich, which was truly good, but wasn't up to the standards that the decor and drinks set us up to expect. The quality does match the prices -  our sandwiches came with frites or other sides, and cost $9.

I'll definitely return here. Especially for the beer.

Yeah doggie, doggie. This is what I'm talking 'bout Madison. 

Food. Service. Atmosphere. 
Check. Check. Check. 

I had the opportunity to whisk Elites Bob S and Scrantz outta their home while they are without kitchen and met them down the street for my first jac attack. I dug it. Lots. First off without even asking the waitress let me know I could try any beer I wanted (it's like she saw the indecisiveness coming outta my pores). She grabbed a taste of Oso;s Hop Whoopin' which on tap is pretty spectacular. Not as hoppy as I thought (score, as I'm just learning to embrace bitter... I'm a naturally cheery person) with grapefruit notes (my fave of the round citrus). 

For din din I went with the fried cod (3rd week in a row I've had fish fry) and I have to tell you, it was one of the best I've had. For frozen, battered deep fried cod, it was pretty darn flaky. You can get potatoes pancakes alongside but I opted for frites and I'm glad I did. They're seasoned really nicely and served hot... like frites should be. (If you get the Mussels which Bob did, frites are served in this cornucopia like contraption that makes it look like they go on for daaaaaaays. Easy sharing!) Scrantz had a roasted veggie salad with an amazing smoked salmon atop. So much smoky flavor in the bite she shared with me. 

All in all I was quite pleased with my first trip and can't wait to go back to try more of the menu. (It's probably no coincidence that my favorite restaurant in Tucson... old stomping grounds... is Jax!)

Brave the construction and  park on the side street and enter a world of amazing flavors!! Tonight my friend and I had the Brussel Sprout Salad. Yum. (The Beet Salad used to be my favorite but not anymore!!) The seafood special was Mahi-mahi with teriyaki glaze, green beans (al dante) and garlic mashed potatoes. OMG!!! Everything was so delicious!! I love this place!  We then topped it off with lime coconut sorbet. A perfect finale.

In a town with so many options, you're not missing much if you skip jacs.  Their beer list is extensive, but that's not saying much in Madison.  I've been twice; once for beers, and once for brunch.

Beers: bottom line, sit at the bar if you want service.  If you're on the other side of the restaurant, you might as well be invisible.  jacs appears to be one of those places where the busier they are, the more likely you are to be taken care of; it's fine for waitstaff to be chatty with the bartenders, of course, but not at the expensive of obviously-waiting customers.  If your brew of choice isn't on tap or on special, be prepared to pay more for a bottle there than you would in most other places.

Saturday brunch: a better experience, over all. Entree pricing is in line with what you might expect elsewhere, and nicely enough, the first bloody mary, screwdriver, or mimosa you order with a brunch entree is $2.  Stick with the mimosa in this case; those received positive reviews, whereas my bloody mary was a disaster of a drink.  The mix is made in-house but is neither spicy nor interesting, but could have been saved if it hadn't been for the lethal layer of vodka floating on top.  Garnished with a lemon slice,a pickle, and a pimiento-stuffed olive and served in a small cocktail glass, this is truly an amateurish effort, and not even worth the $2 addition to the meal.

The food also received mixed reviews; I enjoyed the eggs benedict (the portion of ham served in this dish is both delicious and generous) and the herbed potatoes were quite tasty.  The crepes my friend had were disappointing; she said she can make better.

After a couple tries, I'm done with jacs.  I was surprised to see that they've been open since 2009; the place has a nice ambience but the service, the beverages, and the food all come with the feeling of a restaurant that has very recently opened and is still working out the kinks.  There are better places on Monroe Street and within a couple miles of this place; it's not bad, but you can do far better.

Better food elsewhere.  Nothing was a stand-out.  Tried the cheesecurds...just ok.  Nothing special.  The burger and the turkey sandwich were both just ok.  Both were somewhat flavorless.  The frites were also just ok.

Service was fine and the atmosphere was good.  But, I go for the food and nothing I tasted would draw me back anytime soon.

I really like Jacs for many reasons, but mostly for the gluten free fries cheese curds.  I have eaten here many times and my celiac family members have never been sick.  They have great cocktails and interesting beers on tap.  My only wish is that they had some more basic food items on their main menu for my kids as they get older.  Family friendly and great for vegetarians and gluten free alike!

I went here for dinner and was pretty disappointed to be honest. 

Seating/table: me and my boyfriend went into the restaurant asking for a table for 3 - his mom drove separate and was looking for a spot. While it was a Friday night, there were at least 5 open tables. While we were waiting the 3 minutes for his mom to park, my boyfriend ran to the bathroom leaving me to wait by the door. As I was waiting the hostess approached me and said in a rather rude attitude "we only seat groups If their whole party is here." I explained that our third member was parking the car and I'd be happy to wait to be seated with my whole group. There were 5 empty tables, so I wasn't worried about us getting a table. She insisted I be seated and acted like she was doing me a favor. 1 minute (literally) later, my party joined and we asked to be moved as the table was EXTREMELY wobbly. We were placed by the door and I froze the rest of the night, as there was a huge cold wind gust every time someone came or left. Ugh. 

The beer list was awful. Cinnamon Roll beer? Come on! Crazy flavors does not mean quality and Wisconsin people want quality in a tap house. 

The food was not impressive except for our appetizer, which is also the reason I am giving 3 stars and not 2. I highly recommend the Root Beer Glazed ribs. So delicious and the sweet potato mash it was served on was creamy heaven. I had the Pickled Grape salad and that was pretty tasty too. 

For my entree I had the Grilled Cheese with Brie, goat cheese, fig jam and caramelized onion. Sounds amazing right? That's what I thought too until it landed on my plate. Not melted, almost cold and a half inch of crust with no filling all around. Boooo! So so disappointing. 

The dessert was not good either. Pretzel bread pudding that was so so so dry. 

Not planning on going back anytime soon.

Visited Jacs for the first time last weekend.  First off, this place is popular!  The dinner wait at 6:30 pm was an hour, which was fine with us.  We got on the list, headed across the street for a drink, and eventually made our way back to Jac's bar for another drink and to finish our wait for a table.  The hostess and bar staff were friendly and once seated, so was our server.  

We ordered salads and entrees immediately upon being seated and then... waited.  It seemed like a very long time before our food finally arrived, and when it did our entree came out ahead of the salads.  We rushed through our salads while our food cooled on the table and the end result was we didn't get to enjoy either.  My Caesar salad was bland as was the risotto that accompanied my chicken dish.  For the chicken, one piece was perfectly seasoned with a crisp skin and the other was so salty I couldn't finish it (for balance, my dining partner had the same dish and loved the salty piece and didn't like the white meat piece I enjoyed).

This could have been an off night for the restaurant, so I contacted them the next day to share my experience and disappointingly never heard back.  Docked a star for the lack of follow-through from the restaurant management.

Nice quaint little place on Monroe Street. First timer. Right next to Michaels Frozen Custard. Parking is a little difficult but we found a spot on the street. No problem. I enjoyed actually waving the red flag to cross the street, another first for me. 

Onto the food...we'll wait, let's talk about the Wednesday special which is all about Gluten free products. $2 off gluten free beer taps and there is no up charge for gluten free buns, crust, etc. Good deal I thought. 

I had a Gluten Free Blonde IPA from Alt. Interesting. Not exactly my cup of tea but I had to try it. I'm all about exploring. 

I ordered the Three Little Pigs sandwich. Holy flavor!!! A must have for the hungry. Ham, Bacon and Pork Belly!! Swiss cheese, spinach and a pesto mayo on ciabatta bread. Delicious!! My wife had the smoked salmon BLT. I had a bite and it had this gorgeous smoky flavor to it. Really tasty. 

We both ordered frites with our sandwiches plus the different mayo's. Four different kinds, all unique. Even a cranberry mayo. 

We'll be back. Very cozy and relaxing atmosphere.

I went to Jacs for dinner with a group of approximately 12 ladies on a Monday evening. They warned us in advance that they are not normally able to accomodate groups as large as ours, but since we were planning to arrive early (5:30pm), it would be ok.

I'm so glad they made it work for us because the food was delicious!

We ordered the frites appetizer, which came with 4 dipping sauces, each better than the rest! I ordered the Jacs Classic burger for my entree and was very pleased with my choice! The burger was cooked well and quite tasty. The side salad was simple, with a light dressing.

Our entire group was licking their plates clean before we left.

I definitely recommend Jacs (but maybe don't go with a group of 12 people).

We stopped in here at around 2:00 on a Saturday afternoon. The place was pretty much empty, but we saw the solid Yelp reviews and decided to give it a try.

They are certainly not setup for large groups, and seating even for just 4 people seemed to be about their max. We were hoping to sit by a window since it was nice and sunny out, but the tables by them were only 2 or 3 person tables and they told us they couldn't move them since it would mess up the spacing, which is kind of silly since there was one other table and a few people at the bar at the time.  It is a nice place inside through. I like their big wooden bar along with quite a bit of other woodwork in the place. They have some sort of sound dampening cushions hanging off of the ceiling that are absolutely covered in dust and cobwebs that they really need to do something about, but the rest is charming and comfortable. 

At 2PM, they only had their brunch menu available. I think they switched to a dinner menu at 3. There were some unique options, but they were very limited. They had a couple soups, a few appetizers, a few salads, 3 actual lunch options, and around 7 or 8 brunch selections. Not wanting brunch food, I went with their turkey sandwich. It was delicious, and I would definitely recommend it. There were orders of soup and a salad at the table as well. Nothing real special, but pretty appropriate for the price. The one person that ordered a breakfast option got the salmon benedict, which was very tasty but unfortunately they didn't get it fully deboned before cooking and serving the salmon. 

They have a really nice beer selection, but it seems much overpriced to me. We saw the same beers at other bars for quite a bit less. I suppose if you want a quiet atmosphere to enjoy a beer in, the extra dollar or two is worth it to come here instead of heading to the more busy areas. Our server was fine. Our waters stayed full and we got everything we needed. The one thing that I thought was super awkward was every time anybody at the table said thank you to her for anything, the response was always a monotone "sure". Maybe that is actually a perfectly appropriate response, but it seemed odd to me. 

I certainly wasn't disappointed in the trip here, but I also don't have this on any list of place I need to get back to. The food choices were limited but tasty, although nothing blew any of us away. Their beer includes great options, but is overpriced. The place is really nice, but the atmosphere was dead when we were there. Plenty of good things that might appeal to a different person, but it just wasn't for me.

I've been to this restaurant twice for lunch. Both times I was very satisfied. Service was great, menu is a unique and the preparation of food is top notch. Enjoyed it and would recommend it to others.

I had the Jac's Classic burger and absolutely loved it! The burger was perfect, the frites were amazing, and my Wisco Sour drink was divine. I was also dining with a friend who eats gluten free, and she said it's one of the best gluten free options in town. There was a little bit of a wait, and the food was slightly pricey, but it was well worth it. Highly recommended!
Delicious food, talented bar tenders that know their craft, and the best happy hour in town. Hands down, my favorite place for food and/or drinks in Madison. Thank you for being so awesome, Jac's!

I've been to Jac's multiple times. My fiancée and I agree that its our favorite restaurant in Madison. Whether you get a burger, flatbread, sandwich, salad, or really any other entree, I haven't tried anything there that I don't like. They have a good beer list, and have a nice drink menu. Antonio is almost always our waiter and he rocks.

My husband and I came here with some friends for a double date and it was fantastic! I got a New Fashioned which is a twist on an Old Fashioned and it was tasty. Our waitress gave us some amazing recommendations on food!  My husband had the Saltim Boccawich with frites and it was really good!! I got the Shrimp Rigatoni substituted chicken instead per our waitress's recommendation and it was phenomenal!! The sun dried tomato sauce was the best I have ever had!! I don't know if it all tasted so good because this was the first date my husband and I have had since our daughter was born 11 months ago or if it really was that good but all I know is that we will definitely go back! I wish I had taken pictures but it smelled and tasted so good that I forgot :)

Just be aware that currently Monroe Street is under construction and it is only accessible from the west so it makes it a little difficult getting there and parking can be challenging but it is so worth it!

So many amazing menu options it was very hard to decide! The frites are delicious and the portion is huge. They had a beer flight the night I went and I was very impressed with the selections! I got the suck breast and would get it again in a heartbeat. The Mac and cheese looked fantastic too. Service was ok and the place is small so it was a bit noisy. The minus one star is for the practically nonexistent parking on site. I parked a few blocks down in a residential area and hoped I didn't get a ticket. Perhaps there is parking I don't know about nearby but it all seemed reserved for other businesses or was taken. I hope I can go here again to try more of their menu!

I absolutely loved Jac's!

We stopped in for dinner on a Friday night and it was packed! We had to wait for a table, so we grabbed a drink at the bar, which was also cozy, but had great service from the bartender.

After waiting for about 30 minutes, we sat down and had a friendly, helpful waitress. She told us all about their specials, helped us choose a drink, and answered some questions we had about menu items.

I had the Dupond Pinot Noir to drink. It was pretty good for Pinot and reasonably priced.

For my dinner entree, I got the walnut burger and it was amazing. I love how creative Jac's is with their veggie options, which are abundant. I got it with the fries, which were also great.

There were two things I think the place could improve on: figuring out how to acquire more space and preventing cold air from coming in the front door.

Overall, the place is friendly, tasty, and fun. Everything tasted great, we had reliable service, and the prices were reasonable.  I would highly recommend if you haven't been before, especially for vegetarians and gluten-free folks. I can't wait to go back!
I go there for Happy Hour.  Frequently.   Half-priced St. Bernardus 12 (always on tap) and a phenomenal selection of other local and world taps at Happy Hour defines the term.
I'm in love with their happy hour.... Amazing Bloody Mary's and half priced apps!  Their frites are memorable and highlighted by garlic aolli

Food great. I had the beet salad and an order of frites. Service was so so. Atmosphere great. Great beer and wine selection. Quiche was mediocre. Food home made. Save room for dessert from MIchaels Custard next door.q
This place is good.  The main dishes we had were solid.  However, the red potatoes on the side were totally undercooked.  I've usually had better experiences here though.

Excellent moules & frites. Better than Brasserie V and much better than Graze ones. The starter almond, bacon dates is really good. Like a lot the casual atmosphere. Highly recommended. 

It is ok to go with kids if you go before or after the main crowds. Flatbreads are
Also excellent.

A slight notch above decent bar food. It's a slightly formal venue in a great location. The staff were decent, but nothing to write home about. The food was good, but again would not go out of my way to book a table and go here again. The drink options were decent.

Fries are awesome, but the food was overpriced. A wonderful atmosphere for the family and easily accessible.  The staff was completely helpful in helping to pick out gluten free food.  They have a separate fryer that cooks food to accommodate gluten free individuals.  Check this place out!

I sure like this place! Jacs in a really cute and eclectic part of Madison and it fits right in. I always look for something slightly interesting on the menu and I don't like to order the same thing twice, but at Jacs, the first meal I had was the kind that you go back for - the grapefruit brûlée and walnut burger.

My husband and I came here for dinner around 7pm on a Saturday night.  We were seated immediately.  This was a pleasant surprise since we typically end up waiting a long time at restaurants near the capital.

The waitress was very attentive and friendly. 

The food was delicious!  My husband had duck which was cooked perfectly and had incredible flavor.  The duck had a pomegranate glaze.  It was served with mashed sweet potatoes and some of the best Brussel sprouts I've ever tasted.  I had the wild mushroom poblano risotto which was also good.  We can't wait to come back to try the rest of the menu!

My only complaint is that it can get a bit cold when people open the door, but it's winter, so there's not much they can do about it.  Bring a sweater.

Tip:  Almost everything on the menu can be made gluten free.

Went to Jacs for the first time last night and we were more than impressed with the food, service and atmosphere. The owner happened to be there sitting a few barstools down, and made sure we were treated like royalty. 

We tried the frites - homemade and excellent with all the dipping sauces. Our favorites were the aioli and the spicy buffalo one. The bacon-wrapped dates melted in our mouths. He even went out of the way to make sure one of ours was nut-free due to an allergy. The cheese plate was also a fun and delicious snack, which included sweet pickles, mustard, sliced baguette, apple, 3 different cheeses and a small pour of Serendipity.

Can't wait to go back! I can't stop thinking about those savory dates. Well done!

We've lived nearby for three months and have already been 4 times. Every neighborhood should be lucky enough to have a place like Jac's. The atmosphere at dinner is warm, bustling, and inviting -- like e neighborhood restaurant should feel. 

The beer list is strong and varied -- typically seems to be a mix of local and Belgian. 

Where so many neighborhood places throughout the universe fall short, and Jac's doesn't, is the food. They do both dinner entrees and burgers & fries really well. Okay, the burgers are above really well. One of the best I've ever had. It is hard to order something else.

Only two gripes: 
1) why do so many other people also want to go here on Thursday and Friday night? 
2) burgers are a hair over usually, so be sure to order one temperature lower than you want it.

Went here tonight after reading all the positive reviews on here, and a write up in Madison Originals.  
Wanted the Almond stuffed Dates for our appetizer.  They were out of it.  We skipped the appetizer.
Had the Mussels w/chorizo (me), and the Special (hubby), can't remember the name of it, but it was a fish dish.  The mussels were pretty good, but not nearly enough chorizo.  The fish special was OK, but the size of the fish portion was very small.  They have good beer, and it's priced accordingly.  My diet Coke was flat.
We ordered the Flourless Chocolate cake, and the Bourbon Creme Brulee for dessert.  They were out of the Creme Brulee.  The flourless chocolate cake was the worst example I've ever had.  It was airy, (it's supposed to be super dense), and barely chocolaty (it's supposed to be intense dark chocolate).  It don't know whether they make it or buy it, but either way, it needs to change.  It's simply not good.  This was the first time I've EVER left flourless chocolate cake on the table, uneaten.
The place is very small, but the wait was extremely long for "meh" food.
We won't be returning.
